**Valletta** ([/vəˈlɛtə/](/wiki/Help:IPA/English "Help:IPA/English") [](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/9/9b/LL-Q1860_%28eng%29-Vealhurl-Valletta.wav/LL-Q1860_%28eng%29-Vealhurl-Valletta.wav.mp3 "Play audio")^[ⓘ](/wiki/File:LL-Q1860_(eng)-Vealhurl-Valletta.wav "File:LL-Q1860 (eng)-Vealhurl-Valletta.wav")^ [*və-LET-ə*](/wiki/Help:Pronunciation_respelling_key "Help:Pronunciation respelling key"); [Maltese](/wiki/Maltese_language "Maltese language"): *il-Belt Valletta* ,
pronounced [\[vɐlˈlɛttɐ\]](/wiki/Help:IPA/Maltese "Help:IPA/Maltese")) is the [capital city](/wiki/Capital_city "Capital city") of [Malta](/wiki/Malta "Malta") and one of its 68 [council areas](/wiki/Local_councils_of_Malta "Local councils of Malta"). Located between the [Grand Harbour](/wiki/Grand_Harbour "Grand Harbour") to the east and [Marsamxett Harbour](/wiki/Marsamxett_Harbour "Marsamxett Harbour") to the west, its population as of 2021 was 5,157.^[\[3\]](#cite_note-3)^ As Malta's capital city, it is a commercial centre for shopping, bars, dining, and café life. It is also the southernmost capital of [Europe](/wiki/Europe "Europe"),^[\[4\]](#cite_note-4)^^[\[note 1\]](#cite_note-Cyprus-5)^ and at just 0.61 square kilometres (0.24 sq mi), it is the [European Union](/wiki/European_Union "European Union")'s smallest capital city.^[\[5\]](#cite_note-6)^^[\[6\]](#cite_note-7)^{#cite_ref-7}

Valletta's 16th-century buildings were constructed by the [Knights Hospitaller](/wiki/Hospitaller_Malta "Hospitaller Malta"). The city was named after the Frenchman [Jean Parisot de Valette](/wiki/Jean_Parisot_de_Valette "Jean Parisot de Valette"), who succeeded in defending the island against an Ottoman invasion during the [Great Siege of Malta](/wiki/Great_Siege_of_Malta "Great Siege of Malta"). The city is [Baroque](/wiki/Baroque_architecture "Baroque architecture") in character, with elements of [Mannerist](/wiki/Mannerist_architecture#Mannerist_architecture "Mannerist architecture"), [Neo-Classical](/wiki/Neoclassical_architecture "Neoclassical architecture") and [Modern architecture](/wiki/Modern_architecture "Modern architecture"), though the [Second World War](/wiki/Second_World_War "Second World War") left major scars on the city, particularly the destruction of the [Royal Opera House](/wiki/Royal_Opera_House,_Valletta "Royal Opera House, Valletta"). The city was officially recognised as a [World Heritage Site](/wiki/World_Heritage_Site "World Heritage Site") by [UNESCO](/wiki/UNESCO "UNESCO") in 1980.^[\[7\]](#cite_note-unesco-8)^ The city has 320 monuments, all within an area of 0.55 square kilometres (0.21 sq mi), making it one of the most concentrated historic areas in the world.^[\[7\]](#cite_note-unesco-8)^^[\[8\]](#cite_note-9)^ Sometimes called an "open-air museum",^[\[9\]](#cite_note-10)^ Valletta was chosen as the [European Capital of Culture](/wiki/European_Capital_of_Culture "European Capital of Culture") in 2018. Valletta was also listed as the sunniest city in Europe in 2016.^[\[10\]](#cite_note-11)^^[\[11\]](#cite_note-12)^{#cite_ref-12}

The city is noted for [its fortifications](/wiki/Fortifications_of_Valletta "Fortifications of Valletta"), consisting of [bastions](/wiki/Bastion "Bastion"), [curtains](/wiki/Curtain_wall_(fortification) "Curtain wall (fortification)") and [cavaliers](/wiki/Cavalier_(fortification) "Cavalier (fortification)"), along with the beauty of its [Baroque](/wiki/Baroque "Baroque") palaces, gardens and churches.

------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Valletta&action=edit&section=1 "Edit section: History")\]  
See also: [Mount Sciberras](/wiki/Mount_Sciberras "Mount Sciberras") and [Sciberras Peninsula](/wiki/Sciberras_Peninsula "Sciberras Peninsula")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5f/Malta_-_Valletta_-_Triq_il-Merkanti_12_ies.jpg/220px-Malta_-_Valletta_-_Triq_il-Merkanti_12_ies.jpg)](/wiki/File:Malta_-_Valletta_-_Triq_il-Merkanti_12_ies.jpg) Former mural at *[Is-Suq tal-Belt](/wiki/Is-Suq_tal-Belt "Is-Suq tal-Belt")* illustrating the city's construction

The peninsula was previously called *Xagħret Mewwija* (Mu' awiya -- Meuia; named during the Arab period^[\[12\]](#cite_note-13)^)^[\[13\]](#cite_note-14)^^[\[14\]](#cite_note-15)^ or Ħal Newwija.^[\[15\]](#cite_note-16)^ Mewwija refers to a sheltered place.^[\[16\]](#cite_note-17)^ Some authors state that the extreme end of the peninsula was known as Xebb ir-Ras (Sheb point), of which name origins from the lighthouse on site.^[\[17\]](#cite_note-18)^^[\[18\]](#cite_note-BRILL-19)^ A family which surely owned land became known as *Sceberras* , now a Maltese surname as Sciberras.^[\[19\]](#cite_note-20)^ At one point the entire peninsula became known as Sceberras.{#cite_ref-20}

Recent scholarly studies have however shown that the Xeberras phrase is of Punic origin and means 'the headland' and 'the middle peninsula' as it actually is.^[\[20\]](#cite_note-Article-21)^{#cite_ref-Article_21-0}  

### Order of Saint John {#Order_of_Saint_John}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Valletta&action=edit&section=2 "Edit section: Order of Saint John")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/02/DetalleSiegeMalta.jpg/220px-DetalleSiegeMalta.jpg)](/wiki/File:DetalleSiegeMalta.jpg) The Ottoman army bombs the Knights' Three Cities from the peninsula of Sciberras during the 1565 [Great Siege](/wiki/Great_Siege_of_Malta "Great Siege of Malta"). [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/Malte%2C_La_Valette%2C_co-cath%C3%A9drale_St_Jean.jpg/220px-Malte%2C_La_Valette%2C_co-cath%C3%A9drale_St_Jean.jpg)](/wiki/File:Malte,_La_Valette,_co-cath%C3%A9drale_St_Jean.jpg) The nave of [Saint John's Co-Cathedral](/wiki/Saint_John%27s_Co-Cathedral "Saint John's Co-Cathedral") [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/Grandmaster%27s_palace%2C_Valletta.jpg/220px-Grandmaster%27s_palace%2C_Valletta.jpg)](/wiki/File:Grandmaster%27s_palace,_Valletta.jpg) [Grandmaster's Palace](/wiki/Grandmaster%27s_Palace_(Valletta) "Grandmaster's Palace (Valletta)") [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/15/GrandHarbourValletta1801.jpg/220px-GrandHarbourValletta1801.jpg)](/wiki/File:GrandHarbourValletta1801.jpg) Valletta and the [Grand Harbour](/wiki/Grand_Harbour "Grand Harbour")  1801

The building of a city on the Sciberras Peninsula had been proposed by the [Order of Saint John](/wiki/Knights_Hospitaller "Knights Hospitaller") as early as 1524.^[\[21\]](#cite_note-about-22)^ Back then, the only building on the peninsula was a small watchtower^[\[22\]](#cite_note-23)^ dedicated to [Erasmus of Formia](/wiki/Erasmus_of_Formia "Erasmus of Formia") (Saint Elmo), which had been built in 1488.^[\[23\]](#cite_note-24)^{#cite_ref-24}

In 1552, the Aragonite watchtower was demolished and the larger [Fort Saint Elmo](/wiki/Fort_Saint_Elmo "Fort Saint Elmo") was built in its place.^[\[24\]](#cite_note-cityhistory-25)^{#cite_ref-cityhistory_25-0}

In the [Great Siege](/wiki/Great_Siege_of_Malta "Great Siege of Malta") of 1565, Fort Saint Elmo fell to the [Ottomans](/wiki/Ottoman_Empire "Ottoman Empire"), but the Order eventually won the siege with the help of Sicilian reinforcements. The victorious Grand Master, [Jean de Valette](/wiki/Jean_Parisot_de_Valette "Jean Parisot de Valette"), immediately set out to build a new fortified city on the Sciberras Peninsula to fortify the Order's position in Malta and bind the Knights to the island. The city took his name and was called *La Valletta* .^[\[25\]](#cite_note-26)^{#cite_ref-26}

The Grand Master asked the European kings and princes for help, receiving a lot of assistance due to the increased fame of the Order after their victory in the Great Siege. [Pope Pius V](/wiki/Pope_Pius_V "Pope Pius V") sent his military architect, [Francesco Laparelli](/wiki/Francesco_Laparelli "Francesco Laparelli"), to design the new city, while [Philip II of Spain](/wiki/Philip_II_of_Spain "Philip II of Spain") sent substantial monetary aid. The [foundation stone](/wiki/Cornerstone "Cornerstone") of the city was laid by Grand Master de Valette on 28 March 1566. He placed the first stone in what later became [Our Lady of Victories Church](/wiki/Our_Lady_of_Victories_Church,_Valletta "Our Lady of Victories Church, Valletta").^[\[26\]](#cite_note-journal-27)^{#cite_ref-journal_27-0}

In his book *Dell'Istoria della Sacra Religione et Illustrissima Militia di San Giovanni Gierosolimitano* (English: The History of the Sacred Religion and Illustrious Militia of St John of Jerusalem), written between 1594 and 1602, [Giacomo Bosio](/wiki/Giacomo_Bosio "Giacomo Bosio") writes that when the cornerstone of Valletta was placed, a group of [Maltese](/wiki/Maltese_people "Maltese people") elders said: "*Iegi zimen en fel wardia col sceber raba iesue uquie* " (Which in modern Maltese reads, "*Jiġi żmien li fil-Wardija \[l-Għolja Sciberras\] kull xiber raba' jiswa uqija* ", and in English, "There will come a time when every piece of land on Sciberras Hill will be worth its weight in gold").^[\[27\]](#cite_note-28)^{#cite_ref-28}

De Valette died from a stroke on 21 August 1568 at age 74 and never saw the completion of his city. Originally interred in the church of Our Lady of the Victories, his remains now rest in [St. John's Co-Cathedral](/wiki/St._John%27s_Co-Cathedral "St. John's Co-Cathedral") among the tombs of other Grand Masters of the [Knights of Malta](/wiki/Knights_Hospitaller "Knights Hospitaller").^[\[26\]](#cite_note-journal-27)^{#cite_ref-journal_27-1}

[Francesco Laparelli](/wiki/Francesco_Laparelli "Francesco Laparelli") was the city's principal designer and his plan departed from medieval Maltese architecture, which exhibited irregular winding streets and alleys. He designed the new city on a rectangular [grid plan](/wiki/Grid_plan "Grid plan"), and without any *collacchio* (an area restricted for important buildings). The streets were designed to be wide and straight, beginning centrally from the [City Gate](/wiki/City_Gate_(Valletta) "City Gate (Valletta)") and ending at Fort Saint Elmo (which was rebuilt) overlooking the Mediterranean; certain bastions were built 47 metres (154 ft) high. His assistant was the Maltese architect [Girolamo Cassar](/wiki/Girolamo_Cassar "Girolamo Cassar"), who later oversaw the construction of the city himself after Laparelli's death in 1570.^[\[26\]](#cite_note-journal-27)^{#cite_ref-journal_27-2}

The *[Ufficio delle Case](/w/index.php?title=Ufficio_delle_Case&action=edit&redlink=1 "Ufficio delle Case (page does not exist)")* regulated the building of the city as a [planning authority](/wiki/Planning_authority "Planning authority").^[\[28\]](#cite_note-29)^{#cite_ref-29}

The city of Valletta was mostly completed by the early 1570s, and it became the capital on 18 March 1571 when Grand Master [Pierre de Monte](/wiki/Pierre_de_Monte "Pierre de Monte") moved from his seat at [Fort St Angelo](/wiki/Fort_St_Angelo "Fort St Angelo") in [Birgu](/wiki/Birgu "Birgu") to the [Grandmaster's Palace in Valletta](/wiki/Grandmaster%27s_Palace_in_Valletta "Grandmaster's Palace in Valletta").
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ee/Joseph_Mallord_William_Turner_-_Malta.jpg/220px-Joseph_Mallord_William_Turner_-_Malta.jpg)](/wiki/File:Joseph_Mallord_William_Turner_-_Malta.jpg) [Turner](/wiki/J._M._W._Turner "J. M. W. Turner")'s depiction of the [Grand Harbour](/wiki/Grand_Harbour "Grand Harbour"), [National Museum of Fine Arts](/wiki/National_Museum_of_Fine_Arts_(Malta) "National Museum of Fine Arts (Malta)")

Seven Auberges were built for the [Order's Langues](/wiki/Langue_(Knights_Hospitaller) "Langue (Knights Hospitaller)"), and these were complete by the 1580s.^[\[29\]](#cite_note-30)^^[\[30\]](#cite_note-31)^ An eighth Auberge, [Auberge de Bavière](/wiki/Auberge_de_Bavi%C3%A8re "Auberge de Bavière"), was later added in the 18th century.^[\[31\]](#cite_note-melitensiawth-phw-32)^{#cite_ref-melitensiawth-phw_32-0}

In [Antoine de Paule](/wiki/Antoine_de_Paule "Antoine de Paule")'s reign, it was decided to build more fortifications to protect Valletta, and these were named the [Floriana Lines](/wiki/Floriana_Lines "Floriana Lines") after the architect who designed them, [Pietro Paolo Floriani](/wiki/Pietro_Paolo_Floriani "Pietro Paolo Floriani") of [Macerata](/wiki/Macerata "Macerata").^[\[32\]](#cite_note-33)^ During [António Manoel de Vilhena](/wiki/Ant%C3%B3nio_Manoel_de_Vilhena "António Manoel de Vilhena")'s reign, a town began to form between the walls of Valletta and the Floriana Lines, and this evolved from a suburb of Valletta to [Floriana](/wiki/Floriana "Floriana"), a town in its own right.^[\[33\]](#cite_note-armstrong-34)^{#cite_ref-armstrong_34-0}

In 1634, a [gunpowder factory explosion](/wiki/1634_Valletta_explosion "1634 Valletta explosion") killed 22 people in Valletta.^[\[34\]](#cite_note-35)^ In 1749, Muslim slaves [plotted](/wiki/Conspiracy_of_the_Slaves "Conspiracy of the Slaves") to kill Grandmaster [Pinto](/wiki/Manuel_Pinto_da_Fonseca "Manuel Pinto da Fonseca") and take over Valletta, but the revolt was suppressed before it even started due to their plans leaking out to the Order.^[\[35\]](#cite_note-36)^ Later on in his reign, Pinto embellished the city with [Baroque architecture](/wiki/Baroque_architecture "Baroque architecture"), and many important buildings such as [Auberge de Castille](/wiki/Auberge_de_Castille "Auberge de Castille") were remodeled or completely rebuilt in the new architectural style.^[\[36\]](#cite_note-37)^{#cite_ref-37}

In 1775, during the reign of [Ximenes](/wiki/Francisco_Ximenes_de_Texada "Francisco Ximenes de Texada"), an unsuccessful revolt known as the [Rising of the Priests](/wiki/Rising_of_the_Priests "Rising of the Priests") occurred in which Fort Saint Elmo and [Saint James Cavalier](/wiki/Saint_James_Cavalier "Saint James Cavalier") were captured by rebels, but the revolt was eventually suppressed.^[\[37\]](#cite_note-38)^{#cite_ref-38}  

### French occupation and British rule {#French_occupation_and_British_rule}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Valletta&action=edit&section=3 "Edit section: French occupation and British rule")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/32/Malta_GC._Valletta-1967_%288240967236%29.jpg/220px-Malta_GC._Valletta-1967_%288240967236%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Malta_GC._Valletta-1967_(8240967236).jpg) Early morning in 1967 on the notorious Strait Street known to generations of British Servicemen (especially to sailors on shore leave) as "The Gut". Bars and bordellos abounded, and brawls were common, but its popularity never waned.

In 1798, the [French invaded the island](/wiki/French_occupation_of_Malta "French occupation of Malta") and expelled the Order.^[\[38\]](#cite_note-39)^ After the Maltese rebelled, French troops continued to occupy Valletta and the surrounding harbour area, until they capitulated to the British in September 1800. In the early 19th century, the British Civil Commissioner, [Henry Pigot](/wiki/Henry_Pigot "Henry Pigot"), agreed to demolish the majority of the city's fortifications.^[\[39\]](#cite_note-40)^ The demolition was again proposed in the 1870s and 1880s, but it was never carried out and the fortifications have survived largely intact.^[\[21\]](#cite_note-about-22)^{#cite_ref-about_22-1}

Eventually building projects in Valletta resumed under British rule. These projects included widening gates, demolishing and rebuilding structures, widening newer houses over the years, and installing civic projects. The [Malta Railway](/wiki/Malta_Railway "Malta Railway"), which linked Valletta to [Mdina](/wiki/Mdina "Mdina"), was officially opened in 1883.^[\[40\]](#cite_note-41)^ It was closed down in 1931 after [buses](/wiki/Malta_bus "Malta bus") became a popular means of transport.{#cite_ref-41}

In 1939, Valletta was abandoned as the headquarters of the [Royal Navy Mediterranean Fleet](/wiki/Mediterranean_Fleet "Mediterranean Fleet") due to its proximity to Italy and the city became a flash point during the subsequent two-year long [Siege of Malta](/wiki/Siege_of_Malta_(World_War_II) "Siege of Malta (World War II)").^[\[41\]](#cite_note-Jacobs2016-42)^ [German](/wiki/Nazi_Germany "Nazi Germany") and [Italian](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Italy "Kingdom of Italy") air raids throughout the [Second World War](/wiki/Second_World_War "Second World War") caused much destruction in Valletta and the rest of the harbor area. The [Royal Opera House](/wiki/Royal_Opera_House,_Valletta "Royal Opera House, Valletta"), constructed at the city entrance in the 19th century, was one of the buildings lost to the raids.^[\[24\]](#cite_note-cityhistory-25)^{#cite_ref-cityhistory_25-1}

### Contemporary {#Contemporary}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Valletta&action=edit&section=4 "Edit section: Contemporary")\]

In 1980, the [24th Chess Olympiad](/wiki/24th_Chess_Olympiad "24th Chess Olympiad") took place in Valletta.^[\[42\]](#cite_note-43)^{#cite_ref-43}

The entire city of Valletta has been a UNESCO World Heritage Site since 1980, along with [Megalithic Temples of Malta](/wiki/Megalithic_Temples_of_Malta "Megalithic Temples of Malta") and the [Hypogeum of Ħal-Saflieni](/wiki/Hypogeum_of_%C4%A6al-Saflieni "Hypogeum of Ħal-Saflieni").^[\[7\]](#cite_note-unesco-8)^^[\[43\]](#cite_note-olivergatt-44)^ On 11 November 2015, Valletta hosted the [Valletta Summit on Migration](/wiki/Valletta_Summit_on_Migration "Valletta Summit on Migration") in which European and African leaders discussed the [European migrant crisis](/wiki/European_migrant_crisis "European migrant crisis").^[\[44\]](#cite_note-statewatch-45)^ After that, on 27 November 2015, the city also hosted part of the [Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting 2015](/wiki/Commonwealth_Heads_of_Government_Meeting_2015 "Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting 2015").^[\[45\]](#cite_note-46)^{#cite_ref-46}

Valletta was the [European Capital of Culture](/wiki/European_Capital_of_Culture "European Capital of Culture") in 2018.^[\[46\]](#cite_note-47)^{#cite_ref-47}

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f3/Castille_at_night.jpg/220px-Castille_at_night.jpg)](/wiki/File:Castille_at_night.jpg) [Auberge de Castille](/wiki/Auberge_de_Castille "Auberge de Castille") at night [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/61/Parliament_House_%28Malta%29.jpeg/220px-Parliament_House_%28Malta%29.jpeg)](/wiki/File:Parliament_House_(Malta).jpeg) [Renzo Piano](/wiki/Renzo_Piano "Renzo Piano")'s [Parliament House](/wiki/Parliament_House_(Malta) "Parliament House (Malta)")  

### Local government {#Local_government}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Valletta&action=edit&section=6 "Edit section: Local government")\]

The Valletta Local Council was established by the Local Councils Act of 1993, along with the other [local councils of Malta](/wiki/Local_councils_of_Malta "Local councils of Malta").^[\[47\]](#cite_note-48)^ The first election was held on 20 November 1993. Other elections were held in 1996, 1999, 2002, 2005, 2008, 2013,^[\[48\]](#cite_note-49)^ 2017.^[\[49\]](#cite_note-50)^ The present local council was elected in 2019.^[\[50\]](#cite_note-51)^ The local council is housed in a building in South Street.{#cite_ref-51}

The following people have served as Mayors of Valletta:^[\[51\]](#cite_note-52)^{#cite_ref-52}

* Hector Bruno (1993--1999) ([PN](/wiki/Nationalist_Party_(Malta) "Nationalist Party (Malta)"))
* [Paul Borg Olivier](/wiki/Paul_Borg_Olivier "Paul Borg Olivier") (1999--2008) ([PN](/wiki/Nationalist_Party_(Malta) "Nationalist Party (Malta)"))
* Alexei Dingli (2008--2019) ([PN](/wiki/Nationalist_Party_(Malta) "Nationalist Party (Malta)")) ^[\[52\]](#cite_note-53)^{#cite_ref-53}
* Christian Micallef (2019) ([PN](/wiki/Nationalist_Party_(Malta) "Nationalist Party (Malta)")) ^[\[53\]](#cite_note-54)^{#cite_ref-54}
* Alfred Zammit (2019--) ([PL](/wiki/Labour_Party_(Malta) "Labour Party (Malta)")) ^[\[54\]](#cite_note-55)^{#cite_ref-55}

### National government {#National_government}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Valletta&action=edit&section=7 "Edit section: National government")\]

Valletta is the capital city of Malta,^[\[55\]](#cite_note-56)^ and is the country's administrative and commercial hub.^[\[56\]](#cite_note-57)^ The [Parliament of Malta](/wiki/Parliament_of_Malta "Parliament of Malta") has been housed at the [Parliament House](/wiki/Parliament_House_(Malta) "Parliament House (Malta)") near the city's entrance since 2015: it was previously housed at the [Grandmaster's Palace](/wiki/Grandmaster%27s_Palace_in_Valletta "Grandmaster's Palace in Valletta") in the city centre.^[\[57\]](#cite_note-58)^ The latter palace still houses the Office of the [President of Malta](/wiki/President_of_Malta "President of Malta"),^[\[58\]](#cite_note-president-59)^ while the [Auberge de Castille](/wiki/Auberge_de_Castille "Auberge de Castille") houses the Office of the [Prime Minister of Malta](/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Malta "Prime Minister of Malta"). The [courthouse](/wiki/Courts_of_Justice_building_(Valletta) "Courts of Justice building (Valletta)") and many government departments are also located in Valletta.^[\[59\]](#cite_note-nicpmi-60)^{#cite_ref-nicpmi_60-0}  

Geography {#Geography}
----------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Valletta&action=edit&section=8 "Edit section: Geography")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4a/Prelucrare_3D_pentru_La_Valletta_Harbour.jpg/220px-Prelucrare_3D_pentru_La_Valletta_Harbour.jpg)](/wiki/File:Prelucrare_3D_pentru_La_Valletta_Harbour.jpg) Valletta between its two harbours

The Valletta [peninsula](/wiki/Peninsula "Peninsula") has two natural harbours, [Marsamxett](/wiki/Marsamxett_Harbour "Marsamxett Harbour") and the [Grand Harbour](/wiki/Grand_Harbour "Grand Harbour").^[\[43\]](#cite_note-olivergatt-44)^ The Grand Harbour is Malta's major port, with unloading quays at nearby [Marsa](/wiki/Marsa,_Malta "Marsa, Malta"). A cruise-liner terminal is located along the old seawall of the [Valletta Waterfront](/wiki/Valletta_Waterfront "Valletta Waterfront") that [Portuguese](/wiki/Portugal "Portugal") Grandmaster [Manuel Pinto da Fonseca](/wiki/Manuel_Pinto_da_Fonseca "Manuel Pinto da Fonseca") built.^[\[60\]](#cite_note-61)^{#cite_ref-61}  

### Climate {#Climate}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Valletta&action=edit&section=9 "Edit section: Climate")\]  
Main article: [Climate of Malta](/wiki/Climate_of_Malta "Climate of Malta")

Valletta features a [Mediterranean climate](/wiki/Mediterranean_climate "Mediterranean climate") ([Köppen](/wiki/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification "Köppen climate classification") *Csa*) with very mild, wet winters and warm to hot, slightly long, dry summers, with an average annual temperature above 23 °C (73 °F) during the day and 16 °C (61 °F). Valletta experiences a lack of precipitation during the summer months and most of the precipitation happens during the winter months. Winter temperatures are moderated by the surrounding sea, as a result, the city has very mild winters and a long seasonal lag. The official climate recording station in Malta is at Luqa Airport, which is a few miles inland from Valletta. Average high temperatures range from around 16 °C (61 °F) in January to about 32 °C (90 °F) in August, while average low temperatures range from around 10 °C (50 °F) in January to 23 °C (73 °F) in August.

Cityscape {#Cityscape}
----------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Valletta&action=edit&section=10 "Edit section: Cityscape")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2b/Valletta_Lower_Barrakka_gardens_Malta_2014_2.jpg/220px-Valletta_Lower_Barrakka_gardens_Malta_2014_2.jpg)](/wiki/File:Valletta_Lower_Barrakka_gardens_Malta_2014_2.jpg) [Lower Barrakka Gardens](/wiki/Lower_Barrakka_Gardens "Lower Barrakka Gardens") and its monument of remembrance

The architecture of Valletta's [streets and piazzas](/wiki/List_of_streets_and_piazzas_in_Valletta "List of streets and piazzas in Valletta") ranges from mid-16th century Baroque to [Modernism](/wiki/Modernist_architecture "Modernist architecture"). The city is the island's principal cultural center and has a unique collection of churches, palaces and museums and act as one of the city's main visitor attractions. When [Benjamin Disraeli](/wiki/Benjamin_Disraeli "Benjamin Disraeli"), future British Prime Minister, visited the city in 1830, he described it as "a city of palaces built by gentlemen for gentlemen," and remarked that "Valletta equals in its noble architecture, if it does not excel, any capital in [Europe](/wiki/Europe "Europe")," and in other letters called it "comparable to [Venice](/wiki/Venice "Venice") and [Cádiz](/wiki/C%C3%A1diz "Cádiz")" and "full of palaces worthy of [Palladio](/wiki/Palladio "Palladio")."^[\[63\]](#cite_note-MaltaExpo-64)^^[\[64\]](#cite_note-Collectables-65)^{#cite_ref-Collectables_65-0}

Buildings of historic importance include [St John's Co-Cathedral](/wiki/St_John%27s_Co-Cathedral "St John's Co-Cathedral"), formerly the Conventual Church of the [Knights of Malta](/wiki/Knights_Hospitaller "Knights Hospitaller"). It has the only signed work and largest painting by Michelangelo Merisi da [Caravaggio](/wiki/Caravaggio "Caravaggio").^[\[65\]](#cite_note-Patrick2007-66)^ The [Auberge de Castille et Leon](/wiki/Auberge_de_Castille "Auberge de Castille"), formerly the official seat of the Knights of Malta of the Langue of Castille, Léon and Portugal, is now the office of the [Prime Minister of Malta](/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Malta "Prime Minister of Malta").^[\[59\]](#cite_note-nicpmi-60)^ The [Grandmaster's Palace](/wiki/Grandmaster%27s_Palace_(Valletta) "Grandmaster's Palace (Valletta)"), built between 1571 and 1574 and formerly the seat of the Grand Master of the Knights of Malta, used to house the Maltese Parliament, now situated in a purpose-built structure at the entrance to the city, and now houses the offices of the [President of Malta](/wiki/President_of_Malta "President of Malta").^[\[66\]](#cite_note-67)^{#cite_ref-67}

[Admiralty House](/wiki/Admiralty_House_(Valletta) "Admiralty House (Valletta)") is a Baroque palace dating to the late 1570s. It was the official residence of the Commander-in-Chief of the Mediterranean Fleet during the British era from the 1820s onwards. From 1974 until 2016, it was the site of the [National Museum of Fine Arts](/wiki/National_Museum_of_Fine_Arts_(Malta) "National Museum of Fine Arts (Malta)").

The [Manoel Theatre](/wiki/Manoel_Theatre "Manoel Theatre") ([Maltese](/wiki/Maltese_language "Maltese language"): *Teatru Manoel* ) was constructed in just ten months in 1731, by order of Grand Master [António Manoel de Vilhena](/wiki/Ant%C3%B3nio_Manoel_de_Vilhena "António Manoel de Vilhena"), and is one of the oldest working theatres in Europe. The Mediterranean Conference Centre was formerly the [Sacra Infermeria](/wiki/Sacra_Infermeria "Sacra Infermeria"). Built in 1574, it was one of Europe's most renowned hospitals during the Renaissance. The [fortifications](/wiki/Fortification "Fortification") of the port, built by the Knights as a magnificent series of bastions, demi-bastions, cavaliers and curtains, approximately 100 metres (330 ft) high, all contribute to the unique architectural quality of the city.  

### Neighbourhoods {#Neighbourhoods}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Valletta&action=edit&section=11 "Edit section: Neighbourhoods")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1e/Valletta%2C_Malta_-_2018_%2839570984425%29.jpg/220px-Valletta%2C_Malta_-_2018_%2839570984425%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Valletta,_Malta_-_2018_(39570984425).jpg) Valletta in the foreground and Fort Saint Elmo at the front [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/St_Lazarus_Curtain.jpg/220px-St_Lazarus_Curtain.jpg)](/wiki/File:St_Lazarus_Curtain.jpg) Exterior and interior outlines of Valletta

Valletta contains a number of unofficial neighbourhoods, including:^[\[67\]](#cite_note-melitensiawth-68)^{#cite_ref-melitensiawth_68-0}

* Strada Rjali -- the main thoroughfare, [Triq ir-Repubblika](/wiki/Republic_Street,_Valletta "Republic Street, Valletta")
* l-Arċipierku -- an area close to the [Sacra Infermeria](/wiki/Sacra_Infermeria "Sacra Infermeria"). Its name possibly derives from *[archipelago](/wiki/Archipelago "Archipelago")* since it contains a number of lanes which break up the area into many "islands" of houses, or from *[archi-borgo](/wiki/Borgo_(disambiguation) "Borgo (disambiguation)")* since the area is located just outside [Fort Saint Elmo](/wiki/Fort_Saint_Elmo "Fort Saint Elmo").^[\[68\]](#cite_note-vallettaactionplan-69)^{#cite_ref-vallettaactionplan_69-0}
* il-Baviera -- an area around the English Curtain, bounded by Old Bakery, Archbishop, Marsamxett and St. Sebastian Streets. It is named after [Auberge de Bavière](/wiki/Auberge_de_Bavi%C3%A8re "Auberge de Bavière").^[\[68\]](#cite_note-vallettaactionplan-69)^{#cite_ref-vallettaactionplan_69-1}
* il-Biċċerija -- an area close to il-Baviera, named after the [slaughterhouse](/wiki/Slaughterhouse "Slaughterhouse") which was formerly located there.^[\[68\]](#cite_note-vallettaactionplan-69)^{#cite_ref-vallettaactionplan_69-2}
* il-Kamrata -- an area close to the [Sacra Infermeria](/wiki/Sacra_Infermeria "Sacra Infermeria"). It is named after the Camerata, a spiritual retreat which was demolished in the 19th century and replaced by social housing.^[\[68\]](#cite_note-vallettaactionplan-69)^{#cite_ref-vallettaactionplan_69-3}
* Deux Balles ([Maltese](/wiki/Maltese_language "Maltese language"): *Duwi Balli* ) -- an area close to il-Baviera. The name probably originates from the [French occupation](/wiki/French_occupation_of_Malta "French occupation of Malta").^[\[68\]](#cite_note-vallettaactionplan-69)^{#cite_ref-vallettaactionplan_69-4}
* il-Fossa -- an area close to the Jews' Sally Port and Fort Saint Elmo. It is regarded as the worst maintained area of Valletta.^[\[69\]](#cite_note-70)^{#cite_ref-70}
* [Manderaggio](/wiki/Manderaggio "Manderaggio") ([Maltese](/wiki/Maltese_language "Maltese language"): *il-Mandraġġ* ) -- an area behind Manderaggio Curtain, bounded by St. Mark, St. Lucia, St. Patrick and Marsamxett Streets. This was meant to be a small harbour ([mandracchio](/wiki/Mandracchio "Mandracchio")) but it was never completed, and a slum area developed instead. The slums were demolished in the 1950s and were rebuilt as housing estates.^[\[68\]](#cite_note-vallettaactionplan-69)^{#cite_ref-vallettaactionplan_69-5}
* 

Economy {#Economy}
------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Valletta&action=edit&section=12 "Edit section: Economy")\]

Eurostat estimates the labour force in 2015 for the greater Valletta area at around 91,000 people. This corresponds to a share of just under 50 percent of Malta. As in Malta as a whole, [tourism](/wiki/Tourism_in_Malta "Tourism in Malta") is an important economic sector. The most important tourist zone is the area surrounding the Grand Harbour. For the cruise industry, after several years of planning, work began in 2002 to build the Valletta Waterfront Project, a cruise terminal, in the Grand Harbour.^[\[70\]](#cite_note-71)^ There is also a publishing house in Valletta, Allied Newspapers Ltd., a media company. This company publishes the two market-leading newspapers, *[Times of Malta](/wiki/Times_of_Malta "Times of Malta")* and *The Sunday Times of Malta*.{#cite_ref-71}  

Education {#Education}
----------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Valletta&action=edit&section=13 "Edit section: Education")\]

The Valletta Campus of the [University of Malta](/wiki/University_of_Malta "University of Malta") is situated in the Old University Building. It serves as an extension of the Msida Campus, especially offering international masters programmes.^[\[71\]](#cite_note-72)^{#cite_ref-72}

A [church school](/wiki/Church_school "Church school"), "St. Albert the Great", is also situated in Valletta. The Headmaster is [Alternattiva Demokratika](/wiki/Alternattiva_Demokratika "Alternattiva Demokratika") politician Mario Mallia.^[\[72\]](#cite_note-73)^^[\[73\]](#cite_note-74)^{#cite_ref-74}  

Culture {#Culture}
------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Valletta&action=edit&section=14 "Edit section: Culture")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/13/Renzo_Piano_Pjazza_Teatru_Rjal.jpeg/220px-Renzo_Piano_Pjazza_Teatru_Rjal.jpeg)](/wiki/File:Renzo_Piano_Pjazza_Teatru_Rjal.jpeg) [Renzo Piano](/wiki/Renzo_Piano "Renzo Piano")'s Pjazza Teatru Rjal on the ruins of the [Royal Opera House](/wiki/Royal_Opera_House,_Valletta "Royal Opera House, Valletta") [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3f/Saint_James_Cavalier.jpeg/220px-Saint_James_Cavalier.jpeg)](/wiki/File:Saint_James_Cavalier.jpeg) [Saint James Cavalier](/wiki/Saint_James_Cavalier "Saint James Cavalier") at night [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/16/Merchants_Street_Valletta_%2880653%29.jpg/220px-Merchants_Street_Valletta_%2880653%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Merchants_Street_Valletta_(80653).jpg) Merchants Street at night, with a statue of Saint Dominic

Valletta was designated [European Capital of Culture](/wiki/European_Capital_of_Culture "European Capital of Culture") for 2018.^[\[74\]](#cite_note-75)^ The year was inaugurated with an event called **Erba' Pjazez** (Four Squares), with shows focused in 4 plazas in the city -- [Triton Square](/wiki/Triton_Fountain_(Malta) "Triton Fountain (Malta)"), [St. George's Square](/w/index.php?title=St._George%27s_Square,_Valletta&action=edit&redlink=1 "St. George's Square, Valletta (page does not exist)"), [St. John's Square](/wiki/St_John%27s_Square "St John's Square"), and [Castille Square](/wiki/Auberge_de_Castille "Auberge de Castille") -- along with other shows in other points.^[\[75\]](#cite_note-76)^ This was followed by the unveiling of a public art installation, **Kif Jgħid il-Malti** (Maltese [Sayings](/wiki/Proverb "Proverb")), which featured a number of [Maltese language](/wiki/Maltese_language "Maltese language") proverb figured in gypsum, in order to engage linguistic heritage.^[\[76\]](#cite_note-77)^^[\[77\]](#cite_note-78)^{#cite_ref-78}  

### Saint James Cavalier {#Saint_James_Cavalier}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Valletta&action=edit&section=15 "Edit section: Saint James Cavalier")\]

[Saint James Cavalier](/wiki/Saint_James_Cavalier "Saint James Cavalier"), originally a raised gun platform, was converted into a Centre of Creativity in the year 2000 as part of Malta's Millennium Project. It now houses a small theatre, a cinema, music rooms and art galleries. Various exhibitions are regularly held there. It has welcomed over a million visitors since opening.^[\[78\]](#cite_note-79)^{#cite_ref-79}  

### Music {#Music}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Valletta&action=edit&section=16 "Edit section: Music")\]

The [Valletta International Baroque Festival](/wiki/Valletta_International_Baroque_Festival "Valletta International Baroque Festival") is held every year in January. Jazz music in Malta was introduced in the Strait Street area, frequented by Allied sailors during both [World Wars](/wiki/World_war "World war").^[\[79\]](#cite_note-80)^ Malta's Jazz Festival took place here. Strait Street is also known as *The Gut* . This area is undergoing a programme of regeneration. The city's dual band clubs are the "[King's Own Band Club](/wiki/King%27s_Own_Band "King's Own Band")" ([Maltese](/wiki/Maltese_language "Maltese language"): *L-Għaqda Mużikali King's Own* ) and "La Valette National Philharmonic Society" ([Maltese](/wiki/Maltese_language "Maltese language"): *Is-Soċjetà Filarmonika Nazzjonali La Valette* ).^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^{#cite_ref-80}  

### Carnival {#Carnival}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Valletta&action=edit&section=17 "Edit section: Carnival")\]

Valletta is the scene of the [Maltese Carnival](/wiki/Maltese_Carnival "Maltese Carnival"), held in February each year, leading up to [Lent](/wiki/Lent "Lent").^[\[80\]](#cite_note-cassar-81)^ There were no carnival trucks in 2020 or 2021 due to the [Covid-19 pandemic](/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic "COVID-19 pandemic"), but trucks returned in 2022.^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^{#cite_ref-cassar_81-0}

In 1823 the Valletta carnival was the scene of [a human crush tragedy](/wiki/Carnival_tragedy_of_1823 "Carnival tragedy of 1823") in which at least 110 boys perished.^[\[81\]](#cite_note-hezekiah-82)^{#cite_ref-hezekiah_82-0}  

### Feasts {#Feasts}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Valletta&action=edit&section=18 "Edit section: Feasts")\]

* The feast of [Our Lady of Mount Carmel](/wiki/Our_Lady_of_Mount_Carmel "Our Lady of Mount Carmel") is celebrated on 16 July
* [Saint Paul](/wiki/Paul_the_Apostle "Paul the Apostle")'s feast is celebrated on 10 February
* [Saint Dominic](/wiki/Saint_Dominic "Saint Dominic")'s feast is celebrated in Valletta on 4 August or before
* The feast of [Saint Augustine](/wiki/Augustine_of_Hippo "Augustine of Hippo") is celebrated on the third Sunday after Easter
* The city's residents also conduct an annual procession in honour of [St. Rita](/wiki/St._Rita "St. Rita")

Transport {#Transport}
----------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Valletta&action=edit&section=21 "Edit section: Transport")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6a/Malta_-_Valletta_-_Vjal_Nelson_-_Bus_terminal_Valletta.jpg/220px-Malta_-_Valletta_-_Vjal_Nelson_-_Bus_terminal_Valletta.jpg)](/wiki/File:Malta_-_Valletta_-_Vjal_Nelson_-_Bus_terminal_Valletta.jpg) Bus station at Valletta

[Malta International Airport](/wiki/Malta_International_Airport "Malta International Airport") is 8 kilometres (5.0 mi) from the city in the town of [Luqa](/wiki/Luqa "Luqa"). Malta's [public transport system](/wiki/Transport_in_Malta "Transport in Malta"), which uses buses, operates mostly on routes to or from Valletta, with their central terminus just outside the [city gate](/wiki/City_Gate_(Valletta) "City Gate (Valletta)"). Traffic within the city itself is restricted, with some principal roads being completely pedestrian areas. In 2006, a [park and ride](/wiki/Park_and_ride "Park and ride") system was implemented in order to increase the availability of parking spaces in the city. People can leave their vehicles in a nearby [Floriana](/wiki/Floriana "Floriana") car park and transfer to a [van](/wiki/Van "Van") for the rest of the trip.

In 2007, a [congestion pricing](/wiki/Congestion_pricing "Congestion pricing") scheme was implemented to reduce long-term parking and traffic while promoting business in the city.^[\[86\]](#cite_note-CVA-87)^^[\[87\]](#cite_note-88)^ An [ANPR](/wiki/Automatic_number-plate_recognition "Automatic number-plate recognition")-based automated system takes photos of vehicles as they enter and exit the charging zone and vehicle owners are billed according to the duration of their stay.^[\[86\]](#cite_note-CVA-87)^{#cite_ref-CVA_87-1}

Valletta is served by a fleet of electric taxis which transport riders from 10 points in Valletta to any destination in the city.^[\[88\]](#cite_note-89)^{#cite_ref-89}

As of 2021, an underground [Malta Metro](/wiki/Malta_Metro "Malta Metro") is being planned, with a projected total cost of €6.2 billion,^[\[89\]](#cite_note-90)^ centred on the Valletta urban area.{#cite_ref-90}
